title: The Comedy of Errors (musical)
text:
The Comedy of Errors is a <a href="musical%20theatre">musical</a> with a book and lyrics by <a href="Trevor%20Nunn">Trevor Nunn</a> and music by <a href="Guy%20Woolfenden">Guy Woolfenden</a>. It is based on the <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> play, "<a href="The%20Comedy%20of%20Errors">The Comedy of Errors</a>", which had previously been adapted for the musical stage as "<a href="The%20Boys%20from%20Syracuse">The Boys from Syracuse</a>" by <a href="Richard%20Rodgers">Richard Rodgers</a>, <a href="Lorenz%20Hart">Lorenz Hart</a> and <a href="George%20Abbott">George Abbott</a> in 1938. The London production won the <a href="Olivier%20Award%20for%20Best%20New%20Musical">Olivier Award for Best New Musical</a> in 1977.
Background.
While enjoying a holiday in <a href="Ephesus">Ephesus</a>, Antipholus and Dromio of <a href="Syracuse%2C%20Sicily">Syracuse</a> are mistaken for their long-lost twin brothers Dromio and Antipholus of Ephesus by Adriana, who is married to the latter. Certain her husband's wandering eye has noticed the many temptations awaiting him in town, she is determined to win back his undivided attention. Comic complications arise when she pursues the wrong Antipholus and tries to woo him home. 
The theatre critic <a href="Irving%20Wardle">Irving Wardle</a> said of the score, "It does not give you much to hum on the way out, but it supplies a springboard into dramatic song and dance." The original <a href="Royal%20Shakespeare%20Company">Royal Shakespeare Company</a> production received generally good reviews and was described as "stylish, colorful, and rich in comic detail" by various critics.
Productions.
The Royal Shakespeare Company production, directed by Nunn, choreographed by <a href="Gillian%20Lynne">Gillian Lynne</a>, and designed by <a href="John%20Napier%20%28designer%29">John Napier</a>, opened at the <a href="Royal%20Shakespeare%20Theatre">Royal Shakespeare Theatre</a> in <a href="Stratford-upon-Avon">Stratford-upon-Avon</a> on 29 September 1976. The cast included <a href="Mike%20Gwilym">Mike Gwilym</a> as Antipholus of Ephesus, <a href="Roger%20Rees">Roger Rees</a> as Antipholus of Syracuse, <a href="Nickolas%20Grace">Nickolas Grace</a> as Dromio of Ephesus, <a href="Michael%20Williams%20%28actor%29">Michael Williams</a> as Dromio of Syracuse, and <a href="Judi%20Dench">Judi Dench</a> as Adriana, with <a href="Francesca%20Annis">Francesca Annis</a>, <a href="Richard%20Griffiths">Richard Griffiths</a>, <a href="Griffith%20Jones%20%28actor%29">Griffith Jones</a>, and <a href="John%20Woodvine">John Woodvine</a> in supporting roles. 
The production later transferred to the <a href="Aldwych%20Theatre">Aldwych Theatre</a> in the <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a> in London, where it won the <a href="Laurence%20Olivier%20Award%20for%20Best%20New%20Musical">Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Musical</a> in 1977. 
Philip Casson directed a television production based on Nunn's concept for <a href="ITV%20%28TV%20network%29">ITV</a>. With most of the original cast, the programme was broadcast on 18 April 1978.
<a href="The%20Acting%20Company">The Acting Company</a> staged the musical at the Women's Project Theater in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> in May 2001. It was directed by <a href="John%20Rando">John Rando</a> and choreographed by Joey McKneely. The production then toured the United States.
